div.head: Output Feedback Stabilization for Time-Delay
div.p: Nonlinear Interconnected Systems Using Neural Networks Changchun Hua and Xinping Guan, Senior Member, IEEE Abstract-In this paper, dynamic output feedback control problem is investigated for a class of nonlinear interconnected systems with time delays. Decentralized observer independent of the time delays is first designed. Then, we employ the bounds information of uncertain interconnections to construct the decentralized output feedback controller via backstepping design method. Based on Lyapunov stability theory, we show that the designed controller can render the closed-loop system asymptotically stable with the help of the changing supplying function idea. Furthermore, the corresponding decentralized control problem is considered under the case that the bounds of uncertain interconnections are not precisely known. By employing the neural network approximation theory, we construct the neural network output feedback controller with corresponding adaptive law. The resulting closed-loop system is stable in the sense of semiglobal boundedness. The observers and controllers constructed in this paper are independent of the time delays. Finally, simulations are done to verify the effectiveness of the theoretic results obtained.
Index Terms-Interconnected systems, neural network control, observer design, output feedback, time-delay systems.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: T HE study of interconnected systems is motivated by quite a number of practical applications such as power networks, transportation, aerospace, economics, and management. The decentralized control problem for interconnected systems has received considerable attentions; see [1], [2] and the references therein. The main objectives of decentralized control are to find some feedback laws for adapting the interconnections from the other subsystems where no state information is transferred. The advantage of decentralized control design is to reduce the complexity and therefore to allow the control implementation to be more feasible.

State feedback controllers have been designed to solve the decentralized control problem of nonlinear systems in [3]- [8] and [40]. The adaptive state feedback controllers were constructed in [3] and [5]. Based on backstepping method, the state feedback controller was designed in [7]. With the interconnections unknown, the decentralized neural network controller was presented in [40]. Hierarchical control problem was investigated for interconnected systems via recurrent neural network in [37]. Under the case that the state cannot be totally obtained, the output feedback controllers were used to solve the stabilization problem in [9]- [13]. The case of static output feedback control has been tackled in [9] and [10] where certain conditions were imposed on the class of systems under investigation. Dynamic output feedback control problem was investigated in [11]- [13]. Based on adaptive control technique [11] and [12], the decentralized output feedback controllers were designed for the case when the nominal system is assumed to be of certain structure and the uncertain nonlinear interconnections are bounded by functions of output. In [13], dynamic output feedback controller was constructed based on the reduced-order observer. However, the systems investigated in the aforementioned literature are free of the time delays.

It is well known that time delays are frequently encountered in various engineering fields and can cause the instability. There are instances where delays in the interconnections for many physical systems must be included in the model to account for transmission or information delays. Some results on the decentralized stabilization of large-scale systems with delays in the interconnection patterns have been reported in the literature. In [14] and [15], the authors considered the control problem of the class of time-invariant large-scale interconnected systems free of uncertainties subject to multiple constant delays. In [16], the author considered a class of large-scale interconnected systems with delays, and assumed that all delays were equal and constant, while the result only applied to the system for which the number of inputs and outputs was equal to the number of states [17]. Mahmoud and Bingulac [18] considered the control problem of interconnected time-delay systems and designed the controller based on the knowledge of the uncertainties bounds. The decentralized sliding mode control problem was investigated for the large-scale time-delay systems in [19]. In [20], the authors investigated the stabilization problem of large-scale stochastic systems with time delay and in [21], the authors considered the problem of robust stabilization for a class of time-varying large-scale systems subject to multiple timevarying delays in the interconnections. However, in the aforementioned literature, the investigated interconnected time-delay systems are linear or in part linear. The results obtained are often in the form of Riccati equation and linear matrix inequalities (LMIs). Little attention has been paid to the nonlinear interconnected time-delay systems. How to apply the nonlinear control method such as backstepping method to the control of the time-delay nonlinear systems, especially the interconnected time-delay systems, is a challenging subject. The existence of time delays will render the control problem more complicated and difficult. In [22] and [23], the authors considered the robust control problem for time-delay nonlinear systems via backstepping method. However, the results are not desirable [24], [25]. In [26], we have investigated the control problem for a class of time-delay nonlinear systems via backstepping method and constructed the corresponding output feedback controller. In [28], state feedback controller was successfully constructed to control a class of time-delay nonlinear systems via neural network method.

In this paper, we will investigate the dynamic output feedback control problem for a class of large-scale interconnected systems with time delays. Each subsystem is in the form of the triangular form and includes the internal dynamics. The observer is designed at first. With the bounds information of uncertain interconnections known, we construct the observer-based output feedback controller via backstepping method. By employing Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional method and changing supplying function idea, we prove that the closed-loop system is asymptotically stable. Furthermore, the output feedback control problem is investigated under the case that the bounds of uncertain interconnections are not available. Employing neural network approximation idea, we construct the decentralized output feedback controller. The resulting closed-loop system is stable in the sense of semiglobal boundedness. In this paper, the designed decentralized observer and controllers are independent of the time delays. Finally, computer simulations are done to show the feasibility and effectiveness of the main results.

To the best of our knowledge, little work has been done on the system considered in this paper. The main contributions of the paper are as follows. 1) A new recursive method is developed to investigate the output feedback control problem for a class of interconnected systems with time delays and the designed observer-based controller can render the closed-loop system asymptotically stable. 2) Neural network method is used to deal with the output feedback control problem with the bounding functions unknown and the output feedback controller with adaptive law is proposed to render the closed-loop system stable in the sense of semiglobal boundedness. 3) The recursive method proposed in this paper can also be used to investigate the control problem of nonlinear systems free of time delays, and the output feedback controller design method is simpler than that of former literature.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section II, system descriptions along with necessary assumptions are given. The preliminary knowledge on radial basis function (RBF) neural network is introduced in Section III. In Section IV, the observer and the output feedback controller are designed. The neural network controller is proposed with corresponding adaptive law in Section V. Simulation example is given in Section VI to verify the validity of the main results. Finally, the paper is concluded in Section VII with a brief discussion of the results obtained.

div.head: III. PRELIMINARIES
div.p: In the control engineering, RBF neural network is usually used as a tool for modeling nonlinear functions because of their good capabilities in function approximation. The RBF neural network can be considered as a two-layer network in which the hidden layer performs a fixed nonlinear transformation with no adjustable parameters, i.e., the input space is mapped into a new space. The output layer then combines the outputs in the latter space linearly, therefore, they belong to a class of linearly parameterized networks. In [28], [41], and [42], neural network state feedback controllers were constructed for time-delay nonlinear systems. In [39], the deterministic learning mechanism and the neural learning control scheme were presented. For nonlinear MIMO systems, neural network controllers were constructed in [29]. With the control direction unknown, the authors [38] designed the neural network controller for nonlinear system with triangular structure. Observer-based output feedback controller was designed in [30]. In [31] and [32], decentralized state feedback controllers were constructed for interconnected nonlinear systems via adaptive neural network. In this paper, we will use the neural networks to approximate unknown nonlinear functions and construct the dynamic output feedback controller. div.head: VII. CONCLUSION
div.p: Dynamic output feedback control problem for nonlinear interconnected systems with time delays was investigated.

Adaptive neural network was employed to approximate nonlinear function. First, we designed the dynamic output feedback controller with the bounds of nonlinear functions known based on backstepping design method. With the help of changing Lyapunov function idea, we proved that the constructed controllers could render the closed-loop asymptotically stable. Further, we considered the case that the bounds of uncertain interconnections could not be totally obtained. Decentralized adaptive neural network controllers were proposed. Based on Lyapunov-Krasovskii functional method, we also showed that the resulting closed-loop system was stable in the sense of semiglobal boundedness. Finally, a numerical example was given to illustrate the feasibility and effectiveness of the main results obtained.
